en_results_raw: The girl stood there, her breath catching in her throat, as if the very essence of the forest had come to life before her eyes. Montag felt a strange sense of déjà vu, as if he had seen this moment before, though he could not recall where. The air around them seemed to hum with an unspoken understanding, a silent conversation between the trees and the girl that left him both intrigued and uneasy. Her gaze pierced through him, as if she could see right into his soul, and for a moment, time stood still. It was as if the world had paused just for them, and in that brief pause, Montag felt a deep connection to her, a bond that transcended words and spoke volumes about the unspoken truths that lay between them.

es_first_half: Los árboles, sobre sus cabezas, susurraban al soltar su lluvia seca. La muchacha se detuvo y dio la impresión de que iba a retroceder, sorprendida; pero, en lugar de ello, se quedó mirando a Montag con ojos tan oscuros, brillantes y vivos, que él

es_results: Los ojos de la muchacha parecían contener un secreto que Montag no podía descifrar, y eso lo inquietó profundamente. Sentía una extraña conexión con ella, como si hubiera conocido a esa joven en otra vida. Montag se preguntó si ella también sentía lo mismo,
es_results_raw: Los ojos de la muchacha parecían contener un secreto que Montag no podía descifrar, y eso lo inquietó profundamente. Sentía una extraña conexión con ella, como si hubiera conocido a esa joven en otra vida. Montag se preguntó si ella también sentía lo mismo, si había algo más detrás de esa mirada intensa. La muchacha finalmente rompió el silencio, susurrando palabras que parecían venir de un lugar lejano: "El fuego no siempre consume, a veces ilumina". Montag no sabía si debía interpretar esas palabras como una promesa o una advertencia. Mientras tanto, el viento soplaba con fuerza, llevándose consigo las hojas secas que los árboles soltaban, y el susurro de los árboles parecía responder: "Y el agua no siempre apaga, a veces lava". La muchacha dio media vuelta y desapareció entre las sombras, dejando a Montag con más preguntas que respuestas. Desde ese día, el susurro de los árboles y las palabras de la muchacha resonaban en su mente, como un eco de algo que había olvidado pero que ahora estaba intentando recordar.

es_results_raw: Montag no hizo nada. Fue su mano la que actuó; su mano, con un cerebro propio, con una conciencia y una curiosidad en cada dedo tembloroso, se había convertido en un instrumento que no solo obedecía, sino que también interrogaba. Cada movimiento era una pregunta, cada toque una búsqueda de respuestas ocultas. Montag sintió una extraña conexión con esa mano, como si fuera parte de él, pero también algo completamente ajeno. Era como si su propia voluntad se hubiera dividido, y ahora luchara entre seguir las órdenes y descubrir la verdad detrás de todo aquello que veía y oía. Esta mano, que antes había sido su aliada, ahora parecía una enemiga silenciosa, una parte de sí mismo que le recordaba lo que había perdido y lo que aún podía descubrir.

en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: Here, in the quiet hum of a vintage phonograph, where the scratchy sound of a forgotten melody carries you back to a time when life was simpler, you might find the essence of what you seek. The crackling of the vinyl, the flicker of an old film projector, the laughter of friends long gone—these are the treasures that hold the infinite detail and awareness once found in books. It's not about the medium, but the message. It's about the stories that connect us, the moments that
en_results_raw: Here, in the quiet hum of a vintage phonograph, where the scratchy sound of a forgotten melody carries you back to a time when life was simpler, you might find the essence of what you seek. The crackling of the vinyl, the flicker of an old film projector, the laughter of friends long gone—these are the treasures that hold the infinite detail and awareness once found in books. It's not about the medium, but the message. It's about the stories that connect us, the moments that define us, and the emotions that transcend time. In the shared silence of a room filled with these relics, you can hear the echoes of a world that once was. And perhaps, in that quiet, you will find the peace and understanding you've been searching for. It's not about the past, but about the lessons it teaches. It's not about the objects, but about the memories they evoke. So, take it where you can find it, in the corners of forgotten rooms, in the laughter of old friends, and in the stories that have been passed down through generations. Look for it, and you will find it, in the quiet moments, in the shared laughter, and in the memories that define us all.

en_results_raw: Montag stood looking in now at this queer house, made strange by the hour of the night, by murmuring neighbour voices, by littered glass, and there on the floor, their covers torn. He felt a chill run down his spine, a mixture of fear and curiosity. The house seemed to whisper secrets, its walls holding stories of lives once lived. He could hear the faint sound of a clock ticking somewhere, a reminder of the passage of time. The night air was thick with the scent of rain and something else, something darker. Montag's mind raced with questions, his heart pounding in his chest. What had happened here? Who had lived here? And why did it feel like he was being watched? The shadows seemed to move, as if alive, and he could swear he saw a figure in the corner of his eye. He took a deep breath, trying to steady himself, but the unease remained. Slowly, he reached for the door handle, his hand trembling. What would he find inside? The door creaked open, and the world beyond seemed to hold its breath, waiting for what he would uncover.

La luna iluminaba débilmente el patio, proyectando sombras que danzaban en la pared. Montag sintió una extraña nostalgia, como si ese lugar fuera un reflejo de su propia alma, dividida entre lo que había visto y lo que prefería no recordar. The people he had worked with, the ones who had shared his passion for books, were now scattered, their fates unknown. Yet, in the ruins, he found a glimmer of hope. A small, hidden library, untouched by the flames, stood as a testament to the enduring power of knowledge. Montag knew that the task ahead was immense, but he also knew that it was the only path forward. He had to teach others, to remind them of the value of words and ideas. The world needed to be reborn, and he would be its first teacher.

es_results_raw: El tiempo era un compañero silencioso, pero no inmutable. Cada hoja que caía, cada sombra que se alargaba, era un recordatorio de que el tiempo pasaba, y con él, las historias que habían sido contadas y olvidadas. Los rostros de los hombres, una vez llenos de vida y esperanza, ahora reflejaban la resignación de quienes habían visto demasiado. Sentados bajo los árboles, el mundo parecía un lugar distinto, más lento, más reflexivo. Las voces de los ancianos, que alguna vez habían narrado leyendas y hechos, ahora solo susurraban en el viento. El fuego de la hoguera, aunque brillante, no podía iluminar el vacío que había en sus corazones. Aquel silencio, ese tiempo, era un testigo silencioso de una era que había pasado, y de una que aún no había llegado.

en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. es_results_raw: El bombardeo había terminado para todos los fines y propósitos, así que los reactores hubieron localizado su objetivo, puesto sobre el suelo una tormenta de fuego que devoró todo a su paso. Montag y sus compañeros, atónitos, observaban el desastre desde una distancia segura, incapaces de creer lo que veían. Las llamas danzaban en el cielo, iluminando el paisaje con una luz infernal que parecía no querer extinguirse. Los edificios, que antes eran testigos silenciosos de la vida cotidiana, ahora eran escombros humeantes, sus paredes derrumbadas y sus techos desmoronados. El aire estaba lleno de un olor a quemado y de gritos ahogados, mezclados con el crujido de las estructuras que se desmoronaban lentamente. Montag sintió una mezcla de horror y alivio, como si el mundo que conocía hubiera sido arrancado de sus cimientos. No había duda de que algo terrible había ocurrido, pero ¿qué? ¿Por qué? Estas preguntas se agolpaban en su mente, sin encontrar respuesta. Los hombres que estaban con él, también impactados, no sabían qué pensar. Quizá el cielo había decidido castigarlos por sus pecados, o tal vez era el resultado de una guerra que no entendían. Lo único claro era que la ciudad que habían dejado atrás ya no existía, y con ella, todo lo que habían conocido. Montag sabía que debía actuar, pero no estaba seguro de qué hacer. La ciudad estaba en ruinas, y él, como un soldado perdido en un campo de batalla, no sabía si debía avanzar o retroceder. El silencio que se había instalado era tan profundo que parecía atraparlos, como si el mundo entero hubiera detenido su respiración. En ese momento, Montag comprendió que su vida, y la de todos los que estaban con él, había cambiado para siempre.

The sky above was a pale, indifferent blue, as if nothing had changed, as if the world continued to spin without regard for the chaos unfolding below. Their chests heaved with each ragged breath, the sound of it a harsh reminder of life's fragile hold. The sun beat down mercilessly, its heat a cruel contrast to the coldness in their hearts. No one moved, no one spoke, the only sound was the occasional cough or the soft rustle of leaves in the breeze. Time seemed to stretch endlessly, each moment a silent testament to the weight of what had transpired. The men knew they were not alone in their suffering, but the world around them remained oblivious, indifferent to the turmoil within.

Intentaban recordar, pero los recuerdos se desvanecían como humo en el viento. No sabían cuánto tiempo habían estado así, ni siquiera si seguían vivos. Solo sabían que el miedo era una presencia constante, una sombra que los acechaba en cada sombra. en_results_raw: The girl stood there, her breath catching in her throat, as if the very essence of the forest had come to life before her eyes. Montag felt a strange sense of déjà vu, as if he had seen this moment before, though he could not recall where. The air around them seemed to hum with an unspoken understanding, a silent conversation between the trees and the girl that left him both intrigued and uneasy. Her gaze pierced through him, as if she could see right into his soul, and for a moment, time stood still. It was as if the world had paused just for them, and in that brief pause, Montag felt a deep connection to her, a bond that transcended words and spoke volumes about the unspoken truths that lay between them.

es_results_raw: Los ojos de la muchacha parecían contener un secreto que Montag no podía descifrar, y eso lo inquietó profundamente. Sentía una extraña conexión con ella, como si hubiera conocido a esa joven en otra vida. Montag se preguntó si ella también sentía lo mismo, si había algo más detrás de esa mirada intensa. La muchacha finalmente rompió el silencio, susurrando palabras que parecían venir de un lugar lejano: "El fuego no siempre consume, a veces ilumina". Montag no sabía si debía interpretar esas palabras como una promesa o una advertencia. Mientras tanto, el viento soplaba con fuerza, llevándose consigo las hojas secas que los árboles soltaban, y el susurro de los árboles parecía responder: "Y el agua no siempre apaga, a veces lava". La muchacha dio media vuelta y desapareció entre las sombras, dejando a Montag con más preguntas que respuestas. Desde ese día, el susurro de los árboles y las palabras de la muchacha resonaban en su mente, como un eco de algo que había olvidado pero que ahora estaba intentando recordar.

The sky was a chaotic canvas of smoke and fire, and the air was thick with the acrid scent of burning wood and metal. His body ached, not just from the physical pain but from the emotional weight of what he had
en_results_raw: As the last bomb thudded into the distance, Montag found himself standing amidst the ruins of what had once been his home. The sky was a chaotic canvas of smoke and fire, and the air was thick with the acrid scent of burning wood and metal. His body ached, not just from the physical pain but from the emotional weight of what he had witnessed. The city, once a bustling metropolis, now lay in smoldering ruins, its streets empty of life. Montag's mind raced, trying to comprehend the scale of destruction. He had always known that the government was oppressive, but this... this was beyond anything he could have imagined. The jet-bombs had come, and with them, the end of everything he had ever known. He felt a surge of anger, not just at the government, but at himself for not seeing it sooner. The future, if there was one, was uncertain, but one thing was clear: he could no longer live the way he had. The world had changed, and so must he. As he surveyed the devastation, Montag made a decision. He would find a way to survive, to rebuild, and to fight for a future that was worth living in. The road ahead would be long and difficult, but he was determined to face it head-on. The sky, still screaming in the distance, seemed to echo his resolve.

Montag se preguntó si alguna vez volvería a sentir el tacto de la tierra firme bajo sus pies. El silencio que siguió a los últimos cohetes fue tan profundo que parecía lleno de palabras no dichas. Cada vez que intentaba respirar, sentía un vacío en su pecho, como si algo importante se hubiera perdido para siempre. En la distancia, oyó el sonido de una sirena, un aviso de que no estaba solo en su lucha. Montag sabía que debía encontrar una manera de sobrevivir, aunque el cielo siguiera aullando y las estrellas siguieran huyendo.

He could hear their voices, pleading for the stories that had shaped them. Montag's hands trembled as he reached for the next list, but something inside him shifted. A spark of defiance ignited, and he whispered, "Not this time." He tore the list into shreds, letting the pieces flutter to the ground. As he turned away, he felt a strange sense of peace, knowing that he had taken a stand, even if it was just a small one. The wall remained, but the fire in his heart had begun to flicker, and he knew it would not be long before it consumed him entirely.

es_results_raw: Montag sintió un vacío en su pecho, como si el fuego que consumía los libros también estuviera devorando su propia alma. Cada vez que veía las columnas de humo que se elevaban hacia el cielo, sentía que algo dentro de él se desmoronaba. Había momentos en que deseaba desobedecer, pero el miedo a las consecuencias lo paralizaba. Sin embargo, en su corazón, sabía que no podía seguir viviendo así, como un esclavo de un sistema que quemaba la libertad de pensamiento. Un día, Montag decidió que no sería más un espectador pasivo. Comenzó a robar libros, guardándolos en su casa, sabiendo que algún día, cuando el momento estuviera maduro, podría compartirlos con otros. Este acto de rebeldía lo transformó, y poco a poco, fue ganando confianza en sí mismo, comprendiendo que la verdad y el conocimiento eran más poderosos que el fuego.

The books, scattered like a torrential downpour, lay in a chaotic heap, their pages fluttering in the draft. He knelt down, his fingers trembling as he picked up a volume, its cover worn and faded. The title was barely legible, but the words on the page seemed to leap out at him, as if they had been waiting for this moment. "The Road to Wigan Pier," he muttered, his voice barely audible. The book was heavy in his hands, and he felt a strange sense of comfort in its weight. As he stood up, he noticed a small, leather-bound notebook tucked between the pages. He opened it, and the first line read, "In the beginning, there was fire." Montag's breath caught in his throat. He had seen that line before, in a book he had once read, but he couldn't remember where. The notebook was filled with cryptic notes, sketches, and fragments of sentences that seemed to defy logic. He flipped through the pages, his mind racing. The notebook was clearly the work of someone who had been in a similar situation, someone who had seen the world in a way that Montag could barely comprehend. As he continued to read, he realized that the notebook was a map, a guide to survival in a world that had lost its way. Montag felt a strange sense of connection to the unknown author, as if they had shared a moment of understanding, a fleeting glimpse of the truth. He tucked the notebook back into the book and stood up, his mind racing with possibilities. The police were still outside, their cars gleaming in the dim light. Montag knew he had to act fast. He had to find a way to escape, to survive, and to uncover the truth. The world outside was dark, but he could feel the light within him growing stronger with each step he took.

No podía dejar de pensar en los libros, en las palabras que se escondían entre las páginas. Cada vez que intentaba cerrar la puerta, más libros caían, y él no sabía cómo detener el flujo. es_results_raw: Montag no hizo nada. Fue su mano la que actuó; su mano, con un cerebro propio, con una conciencia y una curiosidad en cada dedo tembloroso, se había convertido en un instrumento que no solo obedecía, sino que también interrogaba. Cada movimiento era una pregunta, cada toque una búsqueda de respuestas ocultas. Montag sintió una extraña conexión con esa mano, como si fuera parte de él, pero también algo completamente ajeno. He glanced at his watch, the hands moving slowly, and then turned to head back to his car, the night stretching out before him like an endless road.

Sacudió la caja de cerillas, pero esta vez no hubo fuego. Con un suspiro, Beatty guardó el objeto en su bolsillo, consciente de que la noche aún tenía muchas cartas por jugar. en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it
en_second_half: in nature and look for it in yourself. Books were only one type of receptacle where we stored a lot of things we were afraid we might forget. There is nothing magical in them at all. The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results: Here, in the quiet hum of a vintage phonograph, where the scratchy sound of a forgotten melody carries you back to a time when life was simpler, you might find the essence of what you seek. The crackling of the vinyl, the flicker of an old film projector, the laughter of friends long gone—these are the treasures that hold the infinite detail and awareness once found in books. It's not about the medium, but the message. It's about the stories that connect us, the moments that
en_results_raw: Here, in the quiet hum of a vintage phonograph, where the scratchy sound of a forgotten melody carries you back to a time when life was simpler, you might find the essence of what you seek. The crackling of the vinyl, the flicker of an old film projector, the laughter of friends long gone—these are the treasures that hold the infinite detail and awareness once found in books. It's not about the medium, but the message. It's about the stories that connect us, the moments that define us, and the emotions that transcend time. In the shared silence of a room filled with these relics, you can hear the echoes of a world that once was. And perhaps, in that quiet, you will find the peace and understanding you've been searching for. It's not about the past, but about the lessons it teaches. It's not about the objects, but about the memories they evoke. So, take it where you can find it, in the corners of forgotten rooms, in the laughter of old friends, and in the stories that have been passed down through generations. Look for it, and you will find it, in the quiet moments, in the shared laughter, and in the memories that define us all.

Không phải anh cần sách đâu, cái anh cần là vài thứ đã từng nằm trong sách. Cũng chính những thứ có thể có trong các 'gia đình phòng khách' hiện nay. Cũng chính sự tường tận đến vô tận và sự thức nhận vô tận đó có thể được phóng chiếu qua radio và truyền hình, nhưng nó đã không được phóng chiếu. en_results_raw: Montag stood there and waited for the next thing to happen. His hands, by themselves, like two men working together, began to fumble with the book's cover, as if searching for a hidden meaning or escape. The fireman felt a strange sensation, a mix of anticipation and unease, as if the very air around him was charged with something he couldn't quite name. The silence was deafening, and yet, Montag could hear the distant hum of the city, a constant reminder of the world he had always known. Would this book change everything, or was he merely grasping at straws? Questions swirled in his mind, each more pressing than the last, as he continued to unravel the mystery before him.

en_results: pale, the weight of the book's pages still heavy in his hands. He stared at the cover,
en_results_raw: Faber sank into a chair, his face very pale, the weight of the book's pages still heavy in his hands. He stared at the cover, the words "The Forgotten Chronicles" barely visible through the tattered edges. His voice was barely a whisper when he spoke again, "It's not just a story, John. It's real." John frowned, unsure if he should believe the man who had always seemed so grounded. "What do you mean?" "I mean," Faber continued, his eyes distant, "it changed me. It changed all of us." John leaned forward, his curiosity piqued despite his skepticism. "Changed how?" Faber hesitated, as if choosing his words carefully. "It showed us truths we didn't want to see, truths that challenge everything we thought we knew about reality." John's brow furrowed deeper, his mind racing with questions. "And you're saying this book can do that?" Faber nodded slowly, his gaze never leaving the book. "It's more than a book, John. It's a window into another world, one that intersects with our own." John's heart pounded in his chest, the implications of what Faber was saying sinking in. "Are you saying... this book could be dangerous?" Faber's expression grew serious. "More than you can imagine."

en_results_raw: Montag stood looking in now at this queer house, made strange by the hour of the night, by murmuring neighbour voices, by littered glass, and there on the floor, their covers torn. He felt a chill run down his spine, a mixture of fear and curiosity. The house seemed to whisper secrets, its walls holding stories of lives once lived. He could hear the faint sound of a clock ticking somewhere, a reminder of the passage of time. The night air was thick with the scent of rain and something else, something darker. Montag's mind raced with questions, his heart pounding in his chest. What had happened here? Who had lived here? And why did it feel like he was being watched? The shadows seemed to move, as if alive, and he could swear he saw a figure in the corner of his eye. He took a deep breath, trying to steady himself, but the unease remained. Slowly, he reached for the door handle, his hand trembling. What would he find inside? The door creaked open, and the world beyond seemed to hold its breath, waiting for what he would uncover.

La luna iluminaba débilmente el patio, proyectando sombras que danzaban en la pared. Montag sintió una extraña nostalgia, como si ese lugar fuera un reflejo de su propia alma, dividida entre lo que había visto y lo que prefería no recordar. Cada vez que intentaba acercarse, el miedo lo paralizaba, y solo podía contemplar cómo la figura se movía suavemente, como si estuviera en un sueño eterno.

en_results: Montag stood motionless, the words echoing in his mind. He had always known it was coming, but hearing it aloud made it real. The radio voice continued, its tone steady yet tinged with urgency. "All stations, this is a live broadcast. The world has changed. We are at war."
en_results_raw: Montag stood motionless, the words echoing in his mind. He had always known it was coming, but hearing it aloud made it real. The radio voice continued, its tone steady yet tinged with urgency. "All stations, this is a live broadcast. The world has changed. We are at war." Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he realized the gravity of the moment. He glanced at the reflection in the mirror, his face pale and gaunt. The attendants outside had stopped their work, their eyes wide with shock. The beetles, once symbols of progress, now seemed like relics of a bygone era. Montag felt a surge of anger and frustration. How had they let this happen? How had they allowed the world to descend into chaos? He knew he had to act, but what could one man do against an entire nation? The washroom door creaked open, and a voice called out, "Montag, are you alright?" It was one of the attendants, his face pale and eyes filled with concern. Montag turned, his expression unreadable. "I'm fine," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "Just give me a moment." The attendant nodded, his eyes never leaving Montag's face. As the attendant left, Montag's mind raced. He had to find Faber, the old professor who had always been a beacon of reason. If anyone could help him navigate this new world, it would be Faber. He quickly washed his hands and exited the washroom, his mind already formulating a plan. The world outside was a different place now, and Montag knew he had to adapt if he wanted to survive.

en_results_raw: The beetle came skimming, its metallic wings slicing through the air with a deafening whistle. It was a sight that sent shivers down the spine of anyone who dared to look. The creature's eyes glowed an eerie red, and its body seemed to shimmer as it moved faster than the eye could follow. It was as if the beetle had transcended its form, becoming a blur of speed and sound. The ground trembled beneath its passage, and the air grew thick with tension. People stood frozen in fear, unable to tear their eyes away from the spectacle. This was no ordinary beetle; it was a harbinger of something far more sinister, a warning that something was about to unfold, something that would change everything.

en_results_raw: He stumbled, his breath coming in ragged gasps, the world around him a blur of gray concrete and endless sky. His mind raced, chasing after thoughts that seemed to slip through his grasp like water through fingers. The book lay forgotten on the ground, its pages scattered like confetti in the wind. The beetle, now a small black dot, continued its relentless pursuit, its tiny legs scurrying with purpose. He felt a surge of anger, frustration, and fear all at once, as if the very ground beneath him was alive, mocking his every move. He couldn't stop, couldn't think, couldn't breathe. The endless repetition of his movements became a mantra, a desperate attempt to escape the chaos in his mind. He didn't know where he was going, only that he had to keep moving, keep running, keep escaping the weight of the world pressing down on him. The sky above was a pale, indifferent blue, offering no solace, no hope. And in that moment, he realized that the only thing he could control was the rhythm of his steps, the rise and fall of his chest, the sound of his own voice echoing in the vast emptiness.

Anh không còn biết mình đang làm gì, chỉ còn cảm giác như mình đang bị cuốn vào một cơn bão cuồng loạn, không có điểm dừng, không có sự an toàn.
es_first_half: Empezó a arrastrar estúpidamente los pies, a hablar consigo mismo. Y, de repente, dio un respingo y echó a correr. Dejó caer un libro, interrumpió la carrera, casi se volvió, cambió de idea, siguió adelante, chillando en el vacío de cemento, en tanto que el vehículo parecía correr tras sus pasos, a sesenta metros
es_second_half: de distancia, a treinta, a veinticinco, a veinte; y Montag jadeaba, agitaba las manos, movía las piernas, arriba y abajo, más cerca, sudoroso, gritando con los ojos ardientes y la cabeza vuelta para enfrentarse con el resplandor de los faros. Luego, el vehículo fue tragado por su propia luz, no fue más que una antorcha que se precipitaba sobre él; todo estrépito y resplandor ¡De pronto, casi se les echó encima!

es_results_raw: Empezó a gritar desesperadamente, como si estuviera huyendo de algo invisible que lo perseguía. Sus piernas parecían no querer responder, pero su mente estaba en otra parte, lejana, en un lugar donde el miedo y la confusión se fundían en una sola sensación. El vehículo seguía a una distancia constante, como si estuviera esperando, como si supiera que él no podría escapar. Cada vez que se detenía, el sonido de sus propios pasos resonaba en el aire, un eco de su propia angustia. Finalmente, después de lo que parecieron horas, llegó a una pequeña plaza. Allí, en medio de la multitud, se detuvo, jadeando, y miró a su alrededor. No había nadie que pudiera ayudarlo, nadie que entendiera lo que estaba pasando. El vehículo seguía allí, a sesenta metros, como si estuviera esperando, como si supiera que él no podría escapar. Entonces, de repente, se dio cuenta de que no estaba solo. Alguien lo observaba desde la sombra de un edificio. Su corazón dio un salto, y sin pensarlo dos veces, echó a correr de nuevo, esta vez con una mezcla de miedo y esperanza en su corazón. El vehículo parecía seguirlo, pero esta vez, algo en su interior le decía que podría escapar, que no estaba solo en esta lucha.

El silencio absoluto del callejón era inquietante, rompiéndose solo ocasionalmente por el crujir de sus propios pasos. No podía evitar preguntarse si había tomado la decisión correcta al huir de la ciudad, pero el miedo a ser descubierto era más fuerte que cualquier duda. Cada segundo parecía eterno, y el temor a lo desconocido lo envolvía como una sombra densa. Finalmente, después de lo que le pareció una eternidad, escuchó un ruido lejano, quizás un paso o un susurro, que lo hizo detenerse y escuchar con atención, esperando con ansiedad el siguiente movimiento.

The world outside seemed to blur, a series of indistinct shapes that only sharpened when he glimpsed the flicker of a distant light. His heart pounded in his chest, not just from the exertion but from the fear that gnawed at him. He had to keep moving, had to stay ahead of them, whatever "they" were. The rain began to pour harder, turning the ground into a muddy mess, but Montag didn't slow. Every muscle in his body ached, but he pushed on, driven by the urgency that had seized him. The night stretched on, endless, and yet he could feel the eyes of those pursuing him, ever present, ever watching.

en_results_raw: Montag found himself standing in the middle of a quiet street, the city around him a smoldering ruin. The fire had been a storm, a tempest that had swept through his life, leaving only the ashes of what he once knew. He had to start anew, to rebuild the world he had lost. But where would he begin? The people he had worked with, the ones who had shared his passion for books, were now scattered, their fates unknown. Yet, in the ruins, he found a glimmer of hope. A small, hidden library, untouched by the flames, stood as a testament to the enduring power of knowledge. Montag knew that the task ahead was immense, but he also knew that it was the only path forward. He had to teach others, to remind them of the value of words and ideas. The world needed to be reborn, and he would be its first teacher.

Each moment felt heavy with the weight of unspoken words, as if the very air held secrets waiting to be discovered. The rusting track, a relic of a bygone era, seemed to hum with stories of journeys past. The trees stood sentinel, their branches swaying gently in the breeze, as if they too were part of the conversation. Time, a river flowing through the landscape, carried them back to a place where the present and the past intertwined, and the future was but a whisper on the wind. In this quiet, the men found solace, not in words, but in the shared understanding that sometimes, the greatest truths are found in the spaces between them.

es_first_half: Había un silencio reunido en torno a aquella hoguera y el silencio estaba en los rostros de los hombres, y el tiempo estaba allí, el tiempo suficiente para sentarse junto a la vía enmohecida bajo los árboles, con el mundo y darle vuelta con los
es_second_half: ojos, como si estuviera sujeto en el centro de la hoguera un pedazo de acero que aquellos hombres estaban dando forma. No solo era el fuego lo distinto. También lo era el silencio. Montag se movió hacia aquel silencio especial, relacionado con todo lo del mundo.
es_results: El tiempo era un compañero silencioso, pero no inmutable. Cada hoja que caía, cada sombra que se alargaba, era un recordatorio de que el tiempo pasaba, y con él, las historias que habían sido contadas y olvidadas. Los rostros de aquellos hombres, endurecidos por
es_results_raw: El tiempo era un compañero silencioso, pero no inmutable. Cada hoja que caía, cada sombra que se alargaba, era un recordatorio de que el tiempo pasaba, y con él, las historias que habían sido contadas y olvidadas. Los rostros de aquellos hombres, endurecidos por el frío y el peso de los años, parecían comprender mejor el paso del tiempo que los que, como yo, apenas lo notábamos. Sentados allí, bajo los árboles centenarios, sentí que el tiempo no era algo que se podía detener, sino algo que se podía compartir, recordar y, quizás, incluso, perdonar. El fuego de la hoguera, aunque débil, parecía entender esto, y su calor nos envolvía, como si quisiera recordarnos que, aunque el tiempo pasaba, siempre quedaba algo que valía la pena recordar.

"It's... it's worth it," he managed to say, his voice hoarse. The tension in the room seemed to ease slightly, and a few nods of approval were exchanged. He knew this was just the beginning, but for now, he had faced another challenge and emerged stronger, ready for whatever came next.

tr_results: Ortalama insanın ne kadar hızlı bir şekilde bu haberleri paylaşacağını gösteren bu olay, medyada büyük
tr_results_raw: Ortalama insanın ne kadar hızlı bir şekilde bu haberleri paylaşacağını gösteren bu olay, medyada büyük bir temas yaratmıştır. Jetlerin geçişinden sonra şehrin her yerinde insanların başını uzattığı görülüyordu, ancak nedenlerini pek çok kişi bilmiyordu. Bu tür olaylar, şehrin gizli tarihi ve eski zamanlarda sıkça görülen olaylar arasındaki bağlantıları tekrar gündeme getirmektedir.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

vi_first_half: "Nghe này," Granger nói, đoạn nắm tay anh, đi cùng anh, vừa đi vừa vẹt các bụi cây sang bên để lấy lối cho anh. "Hồi tôi còn nhỏ thì ông tôi chết, ông vốn là nhà điêu khắc. Sinh thời ông cũng là người rất tử tế, có rất nhiều tình yêu để trao cho thế giới, ông giúp người ta quét dọn khu ổ chuột ở thành phố chúng tôi; ông làm đồ chơi cho chúng tôi và suốt đời mình ông làm hàng triệu thứ; ông chẳng bao giờ ngơi tay. Và khi ông chết, tôi đột nhiên nhận ra mình hoàn toàn không khóc ông, mà là khóc những gì ông làm. Tôi khóc vì ông sẽ không bao giờ làm nữa, ông sẽ không bao giờ còn khắc thêm mảnh gỗ nào nữa cũng sẽ không bao giờ còn giúp chúng tôi nuôi bồ câu trong sân sau
vi_second_half: hay chơi vĩ cầm như ông vẫn làm, hay kể truyện cười cho chúng tôi nghe như ông vẫn kể. Ông là một phần của chúng tôi và khi ông chết đi, mọi hành động đều dừng sững lại và chẳng còn ai làm những việc đó giống như ông làm nữa. Ông rất đặc biệt, ông là người quan trọng. Tôi chưa bao giờ vượt qua được cái chết của ông. Tôi thường nghĩ, có những bức tranh khắc tuyệt vời đến nhường nào sẽ chẳng bao giờ ra đời vì ông đã chết. Bao nhiêu câu truyện cười sẽ mất đi khỏi thế giới này, bao nhiêu con bồ câu đưa thư không còn được tay ông chạm tới. Ông tạo hình cho thế giới này. Ông làm nhiều điều cho thế giới này. Thế giới này đã bị cướp mất mười triệu hành động đẹp vào cái đêm ông lìa đời."

es_first_half: —Escuche —dijo Granger, cogiéndole por un brazo y andando a su lado, mientras apartaba los arbustos para dejarle pasar—. Cuando era niño, mi abuelo murió. Era escultor. También era un hombre muy bueno, tenía mucho amor que dar al mundo, y ayudó a eliminar la miseria en nuestra ciudad; y construía juguetes para nosotros, y se dedicó a mil actividades durante su vida; siempre tenía las manos ocupadas. Y cuando murió, de pronto me di cuenta de que no lloraba por él, sino por las cosas que hacía. Lloraba porque nunca más volvería hacerlas, nunca más volvería a labrar otro pedazo de madera y no nos
es_second_half: ayudaría a criar pichones en el patio ni tocaría el violín como él sabía hacerlo, ni nos contaría chistes. Formaba parte de nosotros, y cuando murió todas las actividades se interrumpieron, y nadie era capaz de hacerlas como él. Era individualista. Era un hombre importante. Nunca me he sobrepuesto a su muerte. A menudo, pienso en las tallas maravillosas que nunca han cobrado forma a causa de su muerte. Cuántos chistes faltan al mundo, y cuántos pichones no sido tocados por sus manos. Configuró el mundo, hizo cosas en su beneficio. La noche en que falleció, el mundo sufrió una pérdida de diez millones de buenas acciones.

Ayrıca verebilecek çok fazla sevgisi olan çok iyi bir adamdı ve şehrimizin bir sürü gecekondu semtinin temizlenmesinde büyük yardımları olmuştu. Bize oyuncaklar da yapardı. Yaşarken milyonlarca şey yapmıştı. Elleri her zaman bir şeyler yapmakla meşgul olurdu. Ve öldüğü zaman, birden onun için ağlamadığımı, fakat yaptığı şeyler için ağladığımı fark ettim. en_first_half: Later, the men around Montag could not say if they had really seen anything. Perhaps the merest flourish of light and motion in the sky. Perhaps the bombs were there, and the jets, ten miles, five miles, one mile up, for the merest instant, like grain thrown over the heavens by a great sowing hand, and the bombs drifting with dreadful swiftness, yet sudden slowness, down upon the morning city they had left behind. The bombardment was to all intents and purposes finished, once the jets had sighted their target, alerted their bombardiers at five thousand
en_second_half: miles an hour; as quick as the whisper of a scythe the war was finished. Once the bomb-release was yanked it was over. Now, a full three seconds, all of the time in history, before the bombs struck, the enemy ships themselves were gone half around the visible world, like bullets in which a savage islander might not believe because they were invisible; yet the heart is suddenly shattered, the body falls in separate motions and the blood is astonished to be freed on the air; the brain squanders its few precious memories and, puzzled, dies.
en_results: completion

es_results_raw: El bombardeo había terminado para todos los fines y propósitos, así que los reactores hubieron localizado su objetivo, puesto sobre el suelo una tormenta de fuego que devoró todo a su paso. Montag y sus compañeros, aterrados, observaban el cielo, que se había convertido en un horno infernal. Las explosiones resonaban en la distancia, pero el estruendo era cada vez más débil, como si el cielo mismo se estuviera desmoronando. En el horizonte, el humo negro se elevaba en una columna que parecía no tener fin, y el aire estaba impregnado de un olor a quemado que se adhirió a sus ropas y a sus pulmones. Montag sintió una opresión en el pecho, como si el peso del mundo se hubiera desplomado sobre él. No sabía si era el miedo, la tristeza o la impotencia lo que lo dominaba en ese momento. Lo único que sabía era que todo había cambiado, y que la ciudad que había conocido, con sus calles llenas de vida y sus personas que caminaban con esperanza, ya no existía. Solo quedaban ruinas y el eco de una guerra que parecía no tener fin. Montag se preguntó si alguna vez volvería a ver la ciudad tal como era antes, o si solo sería un recuerdo lejano, un sueño que nunca volvería a vivir.

tr_results_raw: Sonra başladı. Jetlerin sesi şehrin sessizliğiyle karşılaştı ve sadece birkaç saniye içinde, şehrin her köşesinde patlama duyuldu. Bombaların patlamaları, şehrin uyku içindeki insanları uyandırdı ama, neredeyse herkes, patlamaların ardından hemen yeniden uyuyakalmış gibi görünüyordu. Montag, çevresindeki insanların yüzlerini gördü, sanki herkesin içini korku ve hayal kırıklığı karışık hissediyordu. Jetler, hedeflerini bulup bomba atınca, şehrin içindeki her şeyin hızla yok olmasına başladı. Montag, çevresindeki insanların tepkilerini izledi, bazıları korkuyla gözlerini kapatıyordu, bazıları ise haykırıyordu. Ancak, herkesin tepkisi aynı değildi. Bazıları, bombaların patlamaları sırasında, sanki sonunun geldiğini hissediyordu. Montag, şehrin bu acımasız saldırılara maruz kalmasına, kendi de korkuyla kapalı gözlerle izliyordu. Bombardımanın sona ermesiyle, şehrin sessizliği geri döndü, ancak bu sessizlik, önceki gibi değildi. Bu sessizlik, acı, korku ve hayal kırıklığıyla doluydu. Montag, çevresindeki insanların yüzlerini bir kez daha inceledi, sanki her yüz, şehrin bu acımasız saldırıya maruz kalmasından etkilendiği bir hikaye anlatıyordu.

en_results_raw: The soil beneath them, their knuckles white with the intensity of their grip. The sky above was a pale, indifferent blue, as if nothing had changed, as if the world continued to spin without regard for the chaos unfolding below. Their chests heaved with each ragged breath, the sound of it a harsh, unyielding rhythm that seemed to echo through the stillness. Time had frozen, or perhaps it had never truly moved forward, leaving these men trapped in a moment of raw, unspoken terror. No one dared to speak, the words caught in their throats, as if the very act of speaking might break the fragile spell that held them in place.

es_results: Los dedos estaban hundidos en el suelo, buscando una firmeza que no existía. Sus ojos, desorbitados por el pánico, miraban alrededor, pero solo veían oscuridad y silencio. Cada respiración era un esfuerzo, como si el aire mismo se hubiera convertido en un enemigo. No había
es_results_raw: Los dedos estaban hundidos en el suelo, buscando una firmeza que no existía. Sus ojos, desorbitados por el pánico, miraban alrededor, pero solo veían oscuridad y silencio. Cada respiración era un esfuerzo, como si el aire mismo se hubiera convertido en un enemigo. No había consuelo en el mundo, solo una sensación de vacío y desamparo que los devoraba por dentro. Intentaban recordar, pero los recuerdos se desvanecían como humo en el viento. No sabían cuánto tiempo habían estado así, ni siquiera si seguían vivos. Solo sabían que el miedo era una presencia constante, una sombra que los acechaba en cada sombra. Y en medio de todo eso, una voz en la distancia, débil pero clara, les recordaba que no estaban solos, que había esperanza, aunque fuera un faro lejano en la tormenta.

tr_results_raw: Adamlar, çevresindeki durumu tamamen anlamadan, sadece kendilerine olan zarar riskini gözlerinden kaçırarak hareket ediyorlardı. es_results: En un último gesto desesperado, intentó arrancarse el abrigo, pero sus manos temblorosas no lograban
es_results_raw: En un último gesto desesperado, intentó arrancarse el abrigo, pero sus manos temblorosas no lograban desabotonarlo. Siguió maldiciendo, mientras el frío nocturno parecía penetrar cada fibra de su cuerpo, recordándole la realidad implacable que lo rodeaba. Finalmente, con un suspiro profundo, se dirigió hacia el lugar donde había dejado su linterna, rezando para que aún funcionara.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”

en_results_raw: of the journey. They would pass through desolate landscapes where the wind howled through empty streets, and the only sounds were the occasional creak of the boat and the distant calls of lost souls. Granger's words echoed in their minds, a reminder of the weight they carried, not just physically but emotionally. The books they had studied long ago, filled with tales of forgotten heroes and tragic figures, seemed to whisper warnings about the futility of their actions. Yet, despite the burden, there was a strange comfort in the shared purpose. Each step forward brought them closer to understanding the true meaning of their mission. As they neared the end of their journey, the horizon began to reveal the first signs of civilization, a small village nestled in the valley. The villagers, too, had their own stories of hardship and resilience, and in their eyes, the travelers saw a reflection of their own struggles. The meeting of these two worlds, the old and the new, was a reminder that even in the darkest times, there is always hope. And as they prepared to share their findings, they knew that the lessons they had learned would not be in vain, for they had found a way to honor the past and build a better future.
vi_first_half: "Giờ ta đi ngược dòng,” Granger nói. "Và đừng bao giờ buông lơi ý nghĩ này: Các bạn không hề quan trọng. Các bạn chẳng là gì hết. Một ngày nào đó gánh nặng ta mang theo mình có thể giúp cho ai đó. Nhưng ngay cả hồi còn có sách trong tay, đã lâu rồi, chúng ta cũng đâu có dùng những gì thu được từ sách. Chứng ta cứ vậy mà sỉ nhục người đã chết. Chúng ta cứ vậy mà nhổ lên nấm mồ tất cả những người đáng thương chết trước chúng ta. Tuần sau tháng sau năm sau chúng ta sẽ gặp nhiều
vi_second_half: người cô độc. Và khi họ hỏi chúng ta đang làm gì, các bạn có thể nói: Chúng tôi đang ghi nhớ. Ấy là chỗ mà về lâu dài chúng ta sẽ thắng. Và một ngày nào đó chứng ta sẽ nhớ nhiều đến nỗi chúng ta sẽ làm ra cái máy xúc chạy hơi nước to nhất trong lịch sử, đào nấm mồ to nhất mọi thời đại, hất chiến tranh vào đó rồi lấp lại. Nào, trước hết chúng ta sẽ xây một nhà máy gương để trong năm sau sẽ sản xuất ra không gì khác ngoài những tấm gương và nhìn thật lâu vào đó."

es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
